questions.question: Question 1: Which of the following is not a part of the vulva?
questions.explanation:
Cervix is not a part of the vulva. The vulva includes: • Mons veneris • Labia majora • Labia minora • Clitoris • Vestibule • Vestibular bulb • Greater vestibular glands. The vulva is posteriorly related to the perineum. The triangular space bounded by clitoris, labia minora and fourchette is the vestibule. It is present 
between the labia minora anteriorly and the introitus posteriorly. The posterior part of the 
vestibule between the fourchette and the vaginal introitus is called fossa navicularis. The vestibule 
has 4 openings: 13 
Sold by @itachibot • Urethral opening • Vaginal orifice opening • Bartholin’s duct on either side • Ducts of paraurethral glands

questions.question: Question 2: Which of the following statements is false regarding labia majora?

options.a: They join posteriorly to form the posterior commissure
options.b: It is homologous to scrotum in male
options.c: The round ligament terminates at its posterior end
options.d: It contains sebaceous glands and apocrine glands

questions.explanation:
The round ligament terminates at the anterior end of the labia majora. The labia majora lie on either side of the vulva and join posteriorly to form the posterior 
commissure. The inner side is hairless. Labia majora are homologous to the scrotum in males. 
The labia majora and the mons veneris contain: • Hair follicles • Sebaceous glands • Modified sweat glands, known as apocrine glands The labia minora are two cutaneous folds between the labia major. Anteriorly they enclose the 
clitoris and unite with each other in front and behind the clitoris to form prepuce and frenulum 
respectively. The labia minora are homologous to the ventral aspect of the penis. The clitoris is a small erectile body lying in the anterior-most part of the vulva. The clitoris is 
homologous to glans penis. 14 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 3: A patient presented to the gynecology OPD with the following finding. Which structure in 
men is homologous to the affected structure? 5 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
The given image shows a Bartholin's cyst, which involves the Bartholin's glands. These glands are 
homologous to the male bulbourethral or Cowper glands. The ducts of Bartholin's glands open in the groove between the hymen and the labia minora at 
approximately 5 and 7 o’clock positions. They are stimulated by sexual arousal. The glands 
contain columnar cells that secrete mucus with lubricant properties. Contraction of the 
bulbospongiosus muscle expresses gland secretions. Bartholin's cyst occurs due to obstruction of the ducts of the Bartholin's glands by proteinaceous 
material, or due to infection. Symptomatic or recurrent cysts may require marsupialization or 
gland excision. An infected Bartholin's cyst can lead to an Bartholin's abscess. This requires 
surgical drainage. 15 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question: Question 4: What is the pH of the vagina before puberty?
questions.explanation:
The pH of the vagina before puberty is 7. In adult females, the pH is acidic. Doderlein's bacilli (Lactobacillus sp.) are part of the normal vaginal flora. They produce lactic 
acid from glycogen in the vaginal epithelium and make the vaginal pH acidic. They are present in 
newborns and disappear in 10-14 days. They reappear at puberty and disappear after menopause. 
Vaginal flora also includes microbes such as Clostridium welchii. Vaginal defence mechanisms are influenced by estrogen. In newborns, maternal estrogens 
maintain the defence mechanisms for 10-14 days. After that, the levels wane. During puberty, the 
circulating estrogen maintains the defence mechanism. Note: The pH is higher in the upper part of the vagina due to mixing with alkaline cervical mucus. Doderlein bacteri

questions.question: Question 5: Which of the following is incorrect about relations of the vagina?
questions.explanation:
Bartholin’s gland is present lateral to the vagina. The vagina is related to the following structures: • Anteriorly: • Bladder (upper 1/3rd) • Urethra (lower 2/3rd) • Posteriorly • Pouch of Douglas • Ampulla of the rectum • Perineal body • Laterally 16 
Sold by @itachibot • Mackenrodt's ligament • Levator ani • Bartholin's glands

questions.question:
Question 6: Identify the type of hymen. 6 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
The given image shows cribriform hymen because it has multiple small openings. Based on the shape of its opening, the hymen may be classified as: Other variants of the hymen: The hymen is lined by stratified squamous epithelium on both sides. The hymen is most 
commonly torn posterolaterally or posteriorly. It is replaced by tags after childbirth which are 
called as carunculae myrtiformes. 17 
Sold by @itachibot Hymen

questions.question:
Question 7: A patient with uterine prolapse and urethrocele has weakness in the superficial and deep 
perineal muscles. What level of support is lost here?
questions.explanation:
18 
Sold by @itachibot In the given case scenario, level 3 supports including the superficial and deep perineal muscles are 
lost. This causes urethrocele. DeLancey's levels of support are used to describe the supports of the genital organs.

questions.question:
Question 8: Anteflexion of the uterus is at the level of  
.
questions.explanation:
Anteflexion of the uterus is seen at the level of the internal os. (Mnemonic - V for version, V for vagina) The uterus normally lies in a position of anteversion and anteflexion. In the anteverted position, the external os is directed downward and backwards. On vaginal 
examination, the fingers come in contact with the anterior lip of the cervix as it is the lowest part. When the uterus is retroverted, the cervix is directed downward and forwards. The lowest part of 
the cervix becomes either the external os or its posterior lip. Angle of Anteversion 
Angle of Anteflexion The angle between thecervix 
and vagina The angle betweencervix and 
uterus 90o 
120o 19 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 9: A G3P2L2 woman presents in her third trimester with vaginal leaking. On PV examination, 
the anterior lip of the cervix can be palpated. What is the position of her uterus and the 
ligament that maintains this position?
questions.explanation:
In the given clinical scenario, the uterus is anteverted as the anterior lip of the cervix was 
palpable. The round ligament helps maintain the anteversion of the uterus during pregnancy. However, the anteversion in the non-pregnant uterus is maintained by both the uterosacral 
ligament and round ligament. (Mnemonic - V for version, V for vagina) The uterus normally lies in a position of anteversion and anteflexion. In the anteverted position, the external os is directed downward and backwards. On vaginal 
examination, the fingers come in contact with the anterior lip of the cervix as it is the lowest part. When the uterus is retroverted, the cervix is directed downward and forwards. The lowest part of 
the cervix becomes either the external os or its posterior lip. Anteflexion is seen at the level of the internal os. Angle of anteversion 
Angle of anteflexion Angle between thecervix and 
vagina Angle betweencervix and uter 
us 90o 
120o 20 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 10: A multiparous woman presented with a urethrocele, due to weakness of the urogenital 
diaphragm. What is this structure also known as?
questions.explanation:
The urogenital diaphragm is also known as the triangular ligament. The urogenital diaphragm extends from the pubic arch anteriorly to the central point of the 
perineum posteriorly and consists of two layers of fascia through which pass the vagina and the 
urethra. The central point of the female perineum lies between the vagina and the rectum. Urogenital triangle: • Present between 2 ischiopubic rami • Stretching transversely across the rami there are 3 membranes. • From above downwards the membranes are as follows: • Superior fascia of urogenital diaphragm • Inferior fascia of urogenital diaphragm • Membranous layer of superficial perineal fascia 21 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question: Question 11: What is the cavity of the uterus lined by?

options.a: Single layer of ciliated columnar epithelium
options.b: Double layer of ciliated columnar epithelium
options.c: Single layer of ciliated cuboidal epithelium
options.d: Double layer of ciliated cuboidal epithelium

questions.explanation:
The uterine cavity is lined by a single layer of ciliated columnar epithelium. The wall of the uterus consists of 3 layers: • Perimetrium is the serous coat adherent to the underlying muscle. • Myometrium - it consists of thick bundles of muscles that form 3 distinct layers during 
pregnancy: • Outer longitudinal • Inner circular • Middle interlacing called living ligature • Endometrium - It is the mucous lining of the cavity. It consists of lamina propria and surface 
epithelium which is a single layer of ciliated columnar epithelium.

questions.question:
Question 12: A woman with regular menstrual cycles is undergoing an ultrasound on the 14th day of her 
cycle. What will the endometrial thickness be?
questions.explanation:
During ovulation, the thickness of the endometrium is around 11 mm. Phase

questions.question: Question 13: Which of the following statements is false regarding uterine anatomy?

options.a: Round ligaments receive their blood supply from Sampson's artery
options.b: Transverse cervical ligaments are also called cardinal ligaments
options.c: Uterine innervation is by the pudendal nerve plexus
options.d: Lymphatic drainage is primarily to the obturator, internal and external iliac nodes.

questions.explanation:
The uterus is innervated by the fibers of the uterovaginal plexus, also known as 
the Frankenhauser ganglion. Option A: Round ligaments receive their blood supply from Sampson's artery which represents 
the anastomosis of the uterine artery and ovarian artery. Option B: The cardinal ligaments are also called transverse cervical ligaments or Mackenrodt 
ligaments. They consist primarily of perivascular connective tissue. They attach to the 
posterolateral pelvic walls near the origin of the internal iliac artery and surround the vessels 
supplying the uterus and vagina. Option D: Lymphatic drainage of the uterus is primarily to the obturator and internal and external 
iliac nodes. One theory of endometriosis, states lymphatic spread as cause for seeding in the 
pelvis.

questions.question:
Question 14: A gynecologist is performing a hysterectomy. She accidentally nicks the ureter in the ureteric 
canal as it pierces the Mackenrodt's ligaments. Which vessels are likely to be damaged here?

options.a: Uterine artery above and the uterine plexus of veins below
options.b: Uterine plexus of veins above and the uterine artery below
options.c: Ovarian artery above and the uterine artery below
options.d: Uterine artery above and the ovarian artery below

questions.explanation:
The uterine artery above and uterine venous plexus below are likely to be damaged here, as the 
ureter is present between these vessels. The ureter pierces the Mackenrodt's ligament, forming the ureteric canal. In this canal, the ureter 
is crossed by the uterine artery above and the uterine plexus of veins below, thus being present in 
between the uterine vessels. The ureteric canal provides the necessary room for normal peristalsis, without pressure from the 
surrounding structures. After leaving the ureteric canal, the ureter passes forwards and medially 
to reach the bladder. It is 1-2 cm away from the cervix. 23 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 15: You take a culture swab from the portio vaginalis of a woman having foul smelling vaginal 
discharge. What is this region also known as?
questions.explanation:
Portio vaginalis or exocervix is the other name for the vaginal part of the cervix. Cervix is the lowermost part of the uterus extending from the histological internal os to the 
external os. It is cylindrical in shape measuring 2.5 cm in length and diameter. Cervix is made up of 10% muscle and the rest is collagen, elastin, and proteoglycan. The lining of 
the cervix has the following parts: • Exocervix - also known as portio vaginalis. It is lined by non keratinized stratified squamous 
epithelium. • Endocervix - it is lined by high columnar, ciliated epithelium. • Endocervical glands - secrete alkaline mucus. When enlarged, they form swellings called 
Nabothian follicles/cysts. • Transformation zone - the epithelium gradually changes from columnar to squamous in this 
region.

questions.question: Question 16: What is the cervix: corpus ratio before puberty?
questions.explanation:
The cervix:corpus ratio before puberty is 2:1. The relationship between the length of the cervix and that of the body of the uterus varies with 
age. Age 
Cervix/Corpus ratio Before puberty 
2:1 At puberty 
1:2 24

cervix are both atrophied After menopau

questions.question:
Question 17: The remnants of Wolffian ducts in females are located in 
.
questions.explanation:
The Gartner's duct is a remnant of the Wolffian ducts in women. These are located in the broad 
ligament and the vagina. The Gartner's duct is an embryological remnant of the mesonephric duct/Wolffian duct formed 
during the development of the urinary and reproductive organs. It runs parallel to, but below, the 
fallopian tube in the mesosalpinx. The duct passes downwards by the side of the uterus to the 
level of the internal os where it passes into the tissues of the cervix. It then runs forwards to reach 
the anterolateral aspect of the vaginal wall and may reach as far down as the hymen. The duct can sometimes form a cyst in the broad ligament or in the vagina. It is called Gartner’s 
cyst. It is a benign condition and can be treated with marsupialization.

questions.question: Question 18: Which of the following is false about the contents of the broad ligament?

options.a: Ovarian vessels in its infundibulopelvic part
options.c: Ureter is present the lower portion
options.d: Ovarian ligament in its anterior fold

questions.explanation:
The ovarian ligaments are contained in the posterior fold of the broad ligament. The broad ligament contains the following parts: • Mesosalpinx - it lies between the fallopian tube and ovarian ligament. It contains the pelvic 
vessels - anastomoses between uterine and ovarian arteries. The ovary is attached via ovarian 
ligament through the posterior folds to the mesovarium. 25 
Sold by @itachibot • Mesometrium - it contains the ovarian vessels within the infundibulopelvic ligament. The ureter is present in the inferomedial part of the broad ligament. It is related to the uterine 
artery here and may be damaged during hysterectomy. Note: Broad ligament is not a support of the uterus.

questions.question: Question 19: Where are Peg cells seen?
questions.explanation:
Peg cells are seen in the fallopian tubes. A peg cell is a non-ciliated epithelial cell within the fallopian tube. These cells are also known as 
intercalated or intercalary cells whose function is not yet known. The image below shows pale ciliated cells (arrows) and narrow, dark, non-ciliated peg cells 
(arrowheads).

questions.question: Question 20: What is the longest part of the fallopian tube?
questions.explanation: The longest and widest part of the fallopian tube is the ampulla (5 cm).

questions.question: Question 21: Where is the tunica albuginea of the adult ovary derived from?

options.b: The sub epithelial connective tissue layer

questions.explanation:
Tunica albuginea of the adult ovary is derived from the sub-epithelial connective tissue layer. Structure of the ovary: • Surface epithelium - a single layer of cuboidal cells is present, which later gives rise to the 
surface epithelium of the adult ovary. It is morphologically continuous with the mesothelium of 
the peritoneum. 26 
Sold by @itachibot • The subepithelial connective tissue layer - gives rise to the tunica albuginea of the adult ovary 
and the basement membrane beneath the surface epithelium. • The parenchymatous zone - becomes the cortex and contains the egg nests and ovarian follicles. • Zona vasculosa - becomes the medulla and contains the blood vessels. Hilar cells present here 
are homologous to interstitial cells of testes. They can rarely produce hilar cell tumors of the 
ovary.

questions.question:
Question 22: During the histopathological examination of an ovarian mass, Call-Exner bodies are seen. In 
which of the following layers are these structures seen?
questions.explanation:
Call-Exner bodies are formed by granulosa cells present within the granulosa cell layer of the 
ovary. They are small, distinctive, glandlike structures filled with acidophilic material, resembling 
immature follicles. They are characteristically seen in granulosa cell tumors of the ovary. The image below shows Call-Exner bodies (circled in black). 27 
Sold by @itachibot Graafian follicle: The mature Graafian follicle is spheroidal or ovoid in shape. It contains pent-up secretion known 
as the liquor folliculi. The lining consists of: • Theca externa • Theca interna - contain the theca cells • Granulosa cell layer • Cumulus oophorus - projection of granulosa cells into the cavity of the Graafian follicle. It is also 
called the discus proligerus.

questions.question: Question 23: Where is the sympathetic nerve supply of ovary derived from?
questions.explanation:
28 
Sold by @itachibot The efferent preganglionic sympathetic fibres to the ovary are derived from the T10-T11 spinal 
levels. These fibres travel to the prevertebral ganglia, where they synapse. The postganglionic 
sympathetic fibres arising from these ganglia contribute to the ovarian plexus, which innervates 
the ovary. The ovarian plexus is a network of nerves comprising: • Postganglionic sympathetic fibres • Preganglionic parasympathetic fibres from the sacral outflow (S2-S4) • Visceral afferent fibres (responsible for transmitting sensory signals) The ovarian plexus has two parts based on its connections: • Upper part: Derived from branches of the renal plexus and aortic plexus • Lower part: Derived from the superior and inferior hypogastric plexuses.

questions.question: Question 24: Bleeding during normal menstruation occurs due to rupture of
questions.explanation:
Rupture of the spiral arteries causes bleeding during normal menstruation. This is a branch of the 
uterine artery. The blood supply of the uterus is as follows: Uterine arteryArcuate arteryRadial arteryBasal arterySpiral artery

questions.question:
Question 25: A uterine artery embolization is being planned for a patient with uterine fibroids. Blood flow 
in which of the following arteries will not be affected by this procedure?
questions.explanation:
In the given case scenario, blood flow in the vaginal artery will not be affected, as it is not a 
branch of the uterine artery. The vaginal artery is a branch of the anterior division of the internal 29 
Sold by @itachibot iliac artery. It is homologous to the inferior vesical artery in males. It supplies the vagina and the base of the 
bladder in women. It should not be confused with vaginal branches of the uterine artery. Branches of the uterine artery: • Ureteric branch • Vaginal branches (descending) - these unite to form the anterior and posterior azygos arteries of 
the vagina • Circular cervical branch • Sampson's artery - it runs in under the round ligament. It represents the anastomosis of the 
uterine artery and ovarian artery. • Arcuate--> Radial--> Basal--> Spiral and straight arterioles of the functional layer of the 
endometrium 30 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 26: A patient with stress incontinence required surgical management. While performing a Burch 
colposuspension, the surgeon approached the space of Retzius. What is this space also known 
as?
questions.explanation:
The space of Retzius is the other name for prevesical or retropubic space. Burch colposuspension is a procedure done to relieve stress urinary incontinence. If an 
extraperitoneal approach is selected, the retropubic space is entered by perforating the 
transversalis fascia layer of the anterior abdominal wall. Once the retropubic space is dissected, the bladder neck and the vaginal fascia underneath are 
identified. The bladder is mobilized to the opposite side. At each side of the bladder neck, two to 
four, preferably non■absorbable sutures are placed in the space of Retzius. Note:The presacral space is a retroperitoneal space that lies between the peritoneum of the 
posterior abdominal wall and the sacrum. It contains the superior and inferior hypogastric 
plexuses. The sacral sympathetic trunk lies against the sacrum’s ventral surface. 31 
Sold by @itachibot The Physiology of Conception
